page.title: 11LOCAL HISTORY
page.content:
OKEFORD FITZPAINE The name of the village comes from the fact that the village was close to a ford over the Stour within an oak forest. The parish was granted to the Fitzpaine family in mediaeval times. The parish has also been known as "Fippenny Ockford" and "Ad Ford"(in the Domesday Survey of 1086).
The village appears to have grown along an old trackway running between Shaftesbury and Dorchester. There are prehistoric earthworks on Okeford Hill and Bell Hill. In mediaeval times the village was quite important with its own weekly market and a three day fair each year, both granted by Royal Charter.However, as Sturminster Newton grew in importance in the 17th and 18th centuries, so Okeford declined.
